Award.AwardTitle: SG: Origin and Evolutionary History of Gene Transfer Agents in Marine Bacteria
Award.AbstractNarration:
Exchange of genes is an important evolutionary process that occurs at high frequency within microbial populations, allowing them to adapt quickly to changing environmental conditions. Acquisition of resistance to antibiotics in bacteria is one of the many ways in which such gene swapping impacts society. Because of the potentially tremendous benefit to their survival, bacteria have developed a large arsenal of mechanisms for gene trade. One enigmatic gene exchange mechanism involves shuttling genes packaged in particles (so-called Gene Transfer Agents) that resemble bacterial viruses. This raises many questions about the origin and functionality of this mechanism. How beneficial is it to exchange genes this way? Do Gene Transfer Agents represent former viruses that were "domesticated" by bacteria? Bacterial viruses are numerically the most abundant organisms on Earth. Could many of these viruses in fact be Gene Transfer Agents? Answers to these questions will advance our understanding of how gene exchange contributes to bacterial adaptation. Because of accumulating evidence that Gene Transfer Agents are of use to a microbial population as a whole rather than to an individual cell, this project will also advance our knowledge on the origin and maintenance of cooperation, a long-standing mystery of evolutionary biology. Since bacteria and viruses are key players in all Earth environments, including human bodies, the project will benefit both the scientific community and broader society.

Researchers at Dartmouth College will investigate the above questions via computational analyses of genetic information from marine bacteria. Those bacteria are key players in Earth's nutrient cycling and ocean habitability. Genes encoding Gene Transfer Agents (GTAs) will be identified and extracted from bacterial genomes and oceanic metagenomes. These GTAs will then be rigorously compared to similar genes from bacterial viruses. The comparison will assess the GTA's evolutionary relationship to viruses and the selective pressure exerted on their genes by bacterial hosts. Given the recent discovery of the GTA system and its resemblance to actual viruses, many true GTAs in available genomic sequences could be mistakenly annotated as integrated bacterial viruses. To address this important issue, the researchers will develop a novel bioinformatic method that aims to successfully distinguish Gene Transfer Agents from their viral counterparts. Ultimately, this cross-disciplinary project will contribute to better understanding of oceanic and global elemental cycles and of adaptive evolutionary processes that drive bacterial populations in marine and other environments. The data sets and computer programs generated in this project will be shared with scientific community.

POR.DRECONTENT:
How cooperation arises and persists in biological systems, and what role (if any) exchange of genetic information plays in promoting and maintaining cooperation, are important but poorly understood biological phenomena. The research in this project aimed at advancing our understanding of these phenomena by studying Gene Transfer Agents (GTAs). GTAs are virus-like entities that are encoded within genomes of some microorganisms, are controlled by the hosting microbes and by environmental factors, and can disseminate pieces of DNA (possibly genes) among microorganisms within a population. Since genes of one microorganism can be viewed as shareable products that under specific conditions can benefit other members of a microbial community, mechanisms that promote gene sharing are considered to be important components for maintenance and facilitation of cooperation in a microbial population. GTA-mediated gene exchange is hypothesized to be one such mechanism. This project aimed at deciphering changes and events that led to transformation of a virus (which is a parasite) to a GTA (which is an agent of cooperative behavior) in one group of bacteria.

Temporary integration of a viral genome into the host genome is one of the known strategies for survival and propagation of viruses (as parasites). However, the work under this award demonstrated that in case of GTAs, the integration is not so temporary, since it was inferred that GTAs have likely associated with their bacterial hosts for many millions of years. Analogous to symbioses of bacteria and proto-eukaryotes that eventually led to contemporary mitochondria and plastids, the research under this award demonstrated that the viral progenitors of GTAs have undergone substantial changes over millions of years of residence within bacterial genomes. It was also shown that these changes are more consistent with active maintenance of GTAs by bacteria than attempts to get rid of the parasites. Moreover, the signatures of these changes allowed a development of an automated technique that can decide if an integrated virus in a bacterial genome encodes a GTA or a bona fide virus. When 1,423 bacterial genomes were screened, more than 800 GTAs were discovered, suggesting that GTAs may be more common than currently appreciated. Overall, the carried-out investigations offered novel insights into a process of "domestication" of a virus by bacteria, and provided the research community with a tool that enables identification of GTAs and other related genetic elements in new genomic data.

For all personnel involved in the study, the project provided cross-disciplinary training in biology, computer science, and statistics - a type of training recognized as essential for addressing societal needs of the 21st century. In the PI's research laboratory, postdoctoral fellows, graduate students and undergraduate students gained hands-on experiences in conducting independent research. Four of the trainees were women, who continue to be underrepresented in many STEM fields, particularly in computer science. In addition to research, graduate students and postdoctoral fellows gained experience in mentorship activities. This award also supported outreach activities including development of new classroom materials aimed to improve teaching in biology by using real science examples, and creation of artwork, a video and a picture book that explain GTAs to a broader audience.
